REVIEWThe Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a very pleasantly surprising puzzle game, with a high standard of quality and a humorous undertone.  Any fans of the puzzler-adventure genre should easily find this game enjoyable. Once you start playing you will likely find yourself engrossed by the experience.

It has a much thicker, richer story aspect than many other puzzler-adventure games out there. I was truly entertained by the narrative throughout my entire playthrough. The interesting plot goes a long way to elevate this game above the standard. Furthermore, I thought the graphics were nice and the voice acting was solid, which reinforces the high quality of the writing. The end result is a very enjoyable game with an excellent presentation.

This inherent quality in the writing, atmosphere, and overall presentation results in a game which feels much more true to the Sherlock Holmes brand than the other couple of games I have played that were franchised the intellectual property.  The others feel like standard adventure games with the words Sherlock Holmes" on the title. This game

reviewText: This game was quite disappointing. Despite being a detective game, there is very little actual investigations - the game turns into a simple point and click adventure game pretty quickly. While that is done quite well, and the puzzles themselves are quite good, albeit quite standard for the most part, the narrative structure of a Sherlock Holmes novel just fits terribly. As a game, you expect to be able to influence events as you come across them, not have Sherlock Holmes solve them behind the scenes and present the results afterwards - when you PLAY as him. As a player, I would have liked to be the one to logically think up the clever plots and put them in motion, not switch to Watson and be forced to ignore evidence available to let the plot move along. As a mystery game, this fails spectacularly... which is surprising considering that this game is quite well made - with the exception of some of the worst animations I've seen in a long time.

reviewText:
There are perhaps more flaws to this game than it can get away with. However, the areas in which it excels are the most important aspects of a puzzle game such as this, so I'm inclined to give this a thumbs up overall. Bear in mind though, that this game is probably not everyone's cup of tea, depending on how sensitive you are to annoying details and minor flaws.

Pros:

- The plot is surprising and genuinely intriguing, and keeps you wanting to find out where your next clue leads you.
- The puzzles are sufficiently varied and well-made, and not too easy to solve.
- The atmosphere fits the game and the story perfectly, including some very good voice-work.

Cons:

- While the plot is great, it also contains quite a few loose ends and logical shortcomings. Some of the deductions of Mr. Holmes are so far-fetched you've got to wonder if he's high.
- Some of the puzzles are overly difficult, and most of them has only rudimentary instructions which are of very little help as to what you're actually supposed to do.
- The gameplay is as linear as it gets, and consequently the game has absolutely zero replay-value.
- Animations and lip-sync are far below par. There is also weirdly little visual difference between gameplay and cinematics, which makes you wonder why they bothered.
- Considering the low-level graphics and effects, the game still manages to take up nearly 10 GB of space.
- Running is only marginally faster than walking, which makes some sections fairly tedious.

5/10

reviewText:
This would be a great Sherlock Holmes game if it actually tried to be a Sherlock Holmes game.

What I mean is, it starts off really well, and has two investigations that are very interesting, and very much in the vein of what I expect a Sherlock Holmes game to be. You explore a crime scene, noticing very little details about it, and piece them together in a 'deduction board,' an invention of a game which serves to gamify Holmes' famous deductive reasoning. It does a pretty good job of it, too! I also really liked the ONE scene where you analyze evidence you gathered in the crime scene, as there were quite a few clever minigames that I had fun going through.

The problem being, basically the entire game after that, save for two further, and much smaller, investigations, is literally just a mediocre puzzle adventure game, with a bunch of stupid 'find item -> use item' puzzles, and with far more puzzle boxes than I think should have existed in the late 19th Century? Normally, I wouldn't mind this...but I don't play a game in the Sherlock Holmes universe to go through puzzles that could be in ANY game. I play a Sherlock Holmes game so I can BE Sherlock Holmes, exploring crime scenes and solving them in a way only he could. And you don't even have the excuse there's so little you can do with that, because just look at all the cases in the public domain stories. There's SO many ways to adapt and expand them without ever resorting to stupid puzzle ♥♥♥♥ that even Sierra was doing back in the 80s.

That being said, I do like the voice work of Holmes and Watson, especially Holmes. And the environments are pretty well done, especially for a lower-budget game like this. I wish the engine was a little better, as controlling Holmes and Watson felt like trying to drive a drunken tank at times, but it didn't hamper my experience of the game too much. Though, there WAS a bit too much backtracking, and, yeah, the scene with the dog was completely pointless.

As for the story...it started out pretty well, and then went to ♥♥♥♥ at the end. Minor spoilers from here on out.

So Moriarty's in the game, because apparently you just have to use Moriarty as much as you can, despite there being perfectly fine villains in the mythos. I understand this is part of a series, and he would be suited for 'Holmes' darkest case yet,' but he basically just shows up at the end with little fanfare, and he's just this utterly-generic 'evil for the sake of evil' villain, not at all the criminal mastermind and equal to Holmes he should be. What buildup there is was fine, but his appearance was completely underwhelming.

Not to mention, the final twist at the very end, once Moriarty's dealt with. I actually would have REALLY liked that, and thought it would be a great way to take Holmes as a character...except it's literally JUST introduced seconds before the credits roll. We're given no development, no buildup, it's just a way to cheaply garner audience sympathy right at the very end. It almost comes across as a deus-ex-machina, if it had ANY bearing on the plot. Moriarty doesn't even mention it until he's [SPOILERS] and uses it as his motivation in basically two words.

I would have loved it if we kept meeting Moriarty as the game went on, and he kept hinting about it, and he kept saying he had a reason for his crimes this time around, and it kept us in the dark and serves as a primary motivation to his character, rather than he's just doing it because he's evil.

This game could have used much better writing in general. For being called one of the best Sherlock Holmes games up to now, it's surprisingly amateurish. I just can't give it a recommendation, even though it has just enough of the Holmesian spirit to get me wanting more. If you want to buy it, buy it in a sale when it's 75% off, because I don't think it's worth much more than $5-10.

I really hope the next game, Crime and Punishment, will actually satisfy me. I DO have The Awakening, so maybe that will, too.

reviewText:
Being a fan of the TV show 'Sherlock', I had to play this game. This is my first Sherlock Holmes game and I was pleasantly surprised. The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a point-and-click adventure game where you play as Sherlock (and Watson) trying to resolve the murder of a Reverend in his own church. I won't say more about the story since the main reason of playing this game is to discover that.

The gameplay is faily simple. Where you can interact, there is either a magnifying glass to look at some items or a hand to show that you can take the item or that you can interact with it. That's it. Most of the time, you'll have to look through everything to be sure that you didn't miss any important clue. The rooms are small enough so it's really easy to find everything.

Also, as a detective, there is a deduction board. You'll have to discover every clues to see statements about them. With these facts, it's up to you to choose between 3 answers which one is the right one about what happened in this case. There are multiple questions to be answered and you won't know if you're right until you have all the right answers. It can be hard but if you pay attention to the story, it will be fairly easy. There is also a lot of puzzles in this game. Some are logic and really easy once you understand how they work but some of the puzzles that does NOT involve any deduction/logic can be really hard and frustrating for some people. There is a skip buttons after some minutes so don't worry !

One of the problem in this game is that it's too linear for a detective game. There is no real choice to be made and even if you choose to go to a location instead of another, you'll end up going to both places without any change.

The story is really interesting and there are a lot of twists (I found it similar to the TV show and it's a good thing). The problem (because it's a videogame !) is that Sherock is not as funny as Cumberbatch's Sherlock (but it's understandable since there is no actor involved).

In conclusion, if you like point-and-click games, you'll like this one. It will definitely entertain you for hours ! (I finished the game in about 7-8 hours)

reviewText:
Casual, easy-medium, point and click, adventure story with puzzles.

Very pretty graphics and sound, both ageing well. Nice mix of locations all with good attention to detail. Great story, predictable if you are familiar with Holmes stories, although I was still surprised at one moment and puzzled at another.
Follow the clues, interview, collect clues and tools, analyse the evidence, and complete a few puzzles. All of these points are story driven in a linear fashion, but this is fairly well hidden in the faux open world/choice. It appears difficult to fail as correct choices are made obvious. Some of the puzzles were a little tricky, I liked them the most but they can be skipped if you are not going for 100%.
My favourite part was taking control of a third character.

Recommend not for your 'crayon eaters' but for your more mature still 'spelling rude words on calculators', there is blood and guts, violence and drugs.

reviewText:
Uggh...

I love Sherlock Holmes. I have read the stories over and over since I was a kid. I've watched the old Basil Rathbone films, and the British Sherlock and American Elementary. Enjoyed all of these adaptations, as each has something unique to offer. So of course I was super excited to play a game based on the famous detective.

Then I read the reviews. And got less excited. Waited for it to go on sale, thought I'd try it out despite the criticisms. But I should have listened.

Full disclosure: I haven't finished the game yet. Not sure if I ever will, because I'm already sick of it.


The Bad:

Oh my god the dialogue animations. It's so awful, it completely distracts you from what the character is saying. The opening cutscene with the little kids is the worst; it's almost a joke. It doesn't help that the children look like terrifying soul-less ventriloquist dummies.

Looking for clues doesn't really feel like looking for clues. It feels like wandering around until your cursor turns into a magnifying glass. Which is exactly what it is. No brain activity required.

Sherlock doesn't really feel like Sherlock. I think this was deliberate on the part of the game creators; this is supposed to be a darker, less heroic version of the detective. I see what they were trying to do, but it just felt so... wrong.

The environments are very closed, and you can only travel along a very linear path, even though it looks like you should be able to walk everywhere. It really takes you out of the game.


The Good:

Puzzles are sometimes fun.

The deduction board is a good idea. These were the only moments during the game when I actually felt like I was solving a mystery. But there are no consequences if you get it wrong; just keep clicking until you get it right.

Environments are kind of pretty. Not mind-blowing, but ok.

reviewText:
Conveys the Sherlock Holmes I know and love from the books and short stories, in a way most other visual media won't do.  The puzzles are brilliant.  Very difficult to guess correctly; you certainly have to think about it.  Watson is funny but very like the Watson I'm familiar with from the books. Though a couple of articles of clothing, if I'm to be overly fastidious, are American and not British.  You won't notice.  Only me.

Overall, great game, great story, great puzzles, great Holmes, great Victorian London.  Very impressed by the puzzles.

Real fans of classic point and click adventure games will be ashamed to have played this. The core mechanics of finding and analyzing clues are grossly linear. And as far as I can tell, much of the story is filled out by Holmes' sporadic arbitrary narratives, which relate only vaguely to the clues you've gathered. It makes you feel like you just have to go pick up a prescribed number of rocks before Holmes divulges impossibly-omniscient information on the case. While this may or may not be in the style of traditional Sherlock Holmes, it is not in any way satisfying as a plot progression mechanic in a game.

Also the few puzzle-based asides are entirely self-contained and have little or nothing to do with the story or any details you may have observed. On top of that the movement, much like the GUI, is clunky and annoying, in all 3 of the view modes, and makes you feel like you have nubs for hands.

The deduction board" is a fairly smart mechanic

I just finished The Testament of Sherlock Holmes and can definitely recommend it.

It was a good game with an intersting case to solve. I was a little surprised by the gameplay, as it was not only point-and-click, but also WASD walking around (if you choose that kind of view). I enjoyed this a lot, as it made playing Holmes, Watson and Toby (!) more real.
At times the controls weren't very precise or it took a while until WASD reacted accordingly to my input. The point-and-click mechanisms did function very good for most of the game. Sometimes it was a little difficult to hit the exact spot.

There were plenty of riddles which were all good fun. Sometimes they were a little hard at first, as you get often no explanation what you need to do. But then, you are a detective and your reason of existence if to solve mysteries.

You don't need to know much about the Holmes-universe, but if you do, you'll be in for a treat. As you will be confronted several times with random Holmes-universe trivia :)

reviewText:
All available thumbs up - and some more cut off random passers by for the sake of this review!!!  :D

Now I play a lot of games of different flairs - diversity keeps you young ^^ - and pure adventure games are not what I play most often. BUT those are the games I prefer over every movie, television in general, and even (most) books (btw. I eat books, no reading, I literally eat them ^^). Those are the games that make me stay up all night, squeezing the rest of logic out of my (at very late hours and not everyday) bourbon-clouded mind.

The Testament of Sherlock Holmes meets every possible criteria you'd probably have towards such a game - and that with a superb notion.

The story will suck you in and will leave you not knowing what the hell is going on several occasions (awesome, deep, comprehensible).
It is ALL LOGICAL. The answers are right in front of you, even some clues on top - but logic is mean.
Game mechanics are easy to pick up but enough to give a variety of clue searching, case solving, and more. Some quite unique by the way.
Your playing Sherlock ♥♥♥♥in' Holmes as well as John freakin' Wilson for crying out loud! What's topping that in a very well developed Adventure-Game?!
Have I mentioned the story???? Till this game I had the most fun with Longest Journey, Day of the Tentacle, Siberia, Indiana Jones, Myst, Exile, and the like - but where they have given me fun time in the sense of laughter and/or mind boggling thought-acrobatics this one I treat like a rare tasty wine. I care what happens to the characters; I do not want to look into a walkthrough 'cause I know I have the puzzles solution right there; it drives me; I actually take it seriously :)   Those emotions (let's just call it that) I otherwise only get from scripted movie-like adventures of the sort of The Walking Dead - but this one is a full blooded, full fledged Adventure-Game as you would expect!
You can play (additionally) in first or third person mode but it is an option, a feature you're free to take advantage of. I myself rather play the old fashioned point-and-click way and there is no backdraw whatsoever. Some people were complaining about that for whatever reason... As said, it is a feature - play to your liking, you wont have any disadvantages one way or the other. ;)

If you like adventure games or want to try them or just want to play something wihout much time-fiddling hassle... This might be the thing for you if you came this far reading my review about it. :)

Last words: I DO LOVE THIS GAME!

reviewText:
THE TESTAMENT OF SHERLOCK HOLMES
The best in the long series of Sherlock Holmes adventure games.

Rating 6/10

The best of the series for some time, surpases both Arsène Lupin and Ripper in terms of quality. Voice acting is probably the biggest improvement although it comes with the drawback of having terrible lip sync.

It plays out like previous Sherlock Holmes games but with a slight imbalance between logic and deduction puzzles. There are far too many logic based puzzles that revolve around opening locks on doors, chests and boxes that have complicated puzzle mechanisms.

The majority of these puzzles are fairly easy to figure out but there are three particularly hard puzzles one of which pops at at tne at the very beginning. Thankfully you are able to skip these three puzzles if you spend too long failing at them.

The deduction puzzles work much the same way as they do in Ripper, pieceing toegether the clues that you gather on a deduction board. It's a nice method of explaning the story in an interactive puzzle, the problem is that there are only three deduction boards in the game. It needed more.

So if you like adventure games with puzzle elements then this is one of the better examples, it's by no means great but the series has taken a leap in quality.

reviewText:
Evidently a good game, my dear Watson.

The Testament of Sherlock Holmes, a game I'd never heard of before. The fact that is was 75% off and was recommended by some steam users made me buy it. I never would have expected that it would be one of the best games I've played i the past few months.

The story is pretty obviuos and sometimes predictable, and the ending was, in my opinion, a bit ridiculous. the graphics are pretty okay, considering this is not a triple A title. The animations are sometimes a bit dodgy and funny looking, and the lack of lip sync is also pretty funny if you start to notice it. But these are not the points that make or break a game for me. No, for me it's all about gameplay, and boy did this game do that right.

The searching for clues is sometimes really straight forward, but many times you will be really surprised by where you'll have to look or what you'll have to do to find that one little clue or object you desperately need. And when you do find it, you WILL feel satisfied.

The only little downside to this is a little lack of freedom. For example when you already know what needs do be done next, the game forces you to find that one last clue before you can go any further in the story, even of you already know the solution.

The puzzles are awesome and sometimes you really have to think about them (hardest one took me half an hour of scribbling possible solutions on pieces of paper at my desk).

The dialogue is brilliant, and despite the above named lack of lip sync, the facial expressions are rather good. You can really tell how someone feels by looking at them. The witty remarks of Sherlock Holmes are really entertaining and overall the crime solving duo has been really well represented in the game.

Conclusion: I can't wait untill the next game from this company and give it a solid 8.5/10

The Testament of Sherlock Holmes, a game I'd never heard of before. The fact that is was 75% off and was recommended by some steam users made me buy it. I never would have expected that it would be one of the best games I've played i the past few months.

The story is pretty obviuos and sometimes predictable, and the ending was, in my opinion, a bit ridiculous. the graphics are pretty okay, considering this is not a triple A title. The animations are sometimes a bit dodgy and funny looking, and the lack of lip sync is also pretty funny if you start to notice it. But these are not the points that make or break a game for me. No, for me it's all about gameplay, and boy did this game do that right.

The searching for clues is sometimes really straight forward, but many times you will be really surprised by where you'll have to look or what you'll have to do to find that one little clue or object you desperately need. And when you do find it, you WILL feel satisfied.

The only little downside to this is a little lack of freedom. For example when you already know what needs do be done next, the game forces you to find that one last clue before you can go any further in the story, even of you already know the solution.

The puzzles are awesome and sometimes you really have to think about them (hardest one took me half an hour of scribbling possible solutions on pieces of paper at my desk).

The dialogue is brilliant, and despite the above named lack of lip sync, the facial expressions are rather good. You can really tell how someone feels by looking at them. The witty remarks of Sherlock Holmes are really entertaining and overall the crime solving duo has been really well represented in the game.

Conclusion: I can't wait untill the next game from this company and give it a solid 8.5/10

reviewText:
I've played all the modern Frogwares Sherlock games, and Testament is... this is a bad game. It's just a bad game.

Investigations are poor, with absolutely ludicrous pixel hunting. The sixth sense ability is supposed to assist you in locating interactive hotspots, but it only seems to work if an object is in a direct line of vision, which means if an object is obscured on your screen, it won't show up, leading you to do the ALWAYS FUN GAMEPLAY MECHANIC of running around a room in circles trying to find the one item necessary to trigger the next cutscene.

You do a lot of pointless stuff in this game, that is supposed to reflect poorly on Holmes' credibility, but feels instead like story padding. Whitechapel feels practically like running errands. Back and forth and back and forth. In the prison, back and forth and back and forth. Backtracking is nothing new to adventure games but because every area of the game is its own chapter, you're not backtracking to other locations, you're backtracking within the same location, which just adds to the tedium.

The story wants you to take itself seriously but yikes. (SPOILERS!) Why are there saturday morning cartoon scenes in an attic with hilarious looking 3d models during this game about vicious murders? Why is Watson fooled by the warden's sudden RIDICULOUS FORCED GERMAN ACCENT? Since when did Moriarty become Kefka from Final Fantasy 6?  There are times when the story in this game felt sillier than the Cthulhu game, but at least the Cthulhu game knew it was camp! There's always been ridiculous elements to Sherlock Holmes cases, but this game wants you to believe it's the darkest and grimest game yet-- but it's so goofy!!

Maybe the engine just doesn't hold up anymore. Or maybe Sherlock Holmes needs to shed the current construct of puzzles and busywork. Perhaps a game more along the lines of Walking Dead/Gone Home but with a detective/invstigation slant? All I know is the gameplay of Testament is flat out bad and the story doesn't save it, and I enjoyed it far less than Awakened, Nemesis, and Jack the Ripper.

reviewText:
Everything looks quite nice, especially the setting. For the most part I have no problem with the graphics, a touch old-fashioned though they may be.  The poor lip-syncing and the harrowingly dead eyes of everyone except perhaps Holmes, however, are annoying. Not to mention those pictures of the judges, which were just embarrassing...

The plot is interesting and suitably grim, although there were some parts which made little sense. The frame story, I'm sorry to say, I didn't care for at all. The dialogue is interesting, occasionally even quite funny, and there isn't an excess of pointless blather. Holmes' witty retorts deserve a mention of their own, and I quite liked his voice-actor. I also liked the fact that you get to play several characters, not just him. However, there were instances where I wish I had been given freer hands to interrogate people and arrive at conclusions.

The puzzles aren't patronisingly easy, nor nerve-wrackingly difficult. Nor are they repetitive. There were a couple which I chose to skip after three or four tries simply because they didn't exactly fall within my field of expertise. Some might find the lack of instructions a nuisance, but I didn't mind.

All in all, I quite enjoyed it, even if occasionally I did get frustrated. 7/10

reviewText:
I picked up this game because it was on sale and wanted to try it because I really didn't know much about Sherlock Holmes. Unfortunately, I didn't like the game very much because of three reasons:

1. The Characters: I went into this game not knowing much about Sherlock Holmes (I never read any of the stories and only knew him as a famous detective). He, in my opinion, is nothing but an arrogant a**hole who talks down to everyone while making himself out to be hot sh*t. He goes around constantly breaking the law in the name of his investigations and then expects everyone to accept his deductions. A perfect example of this is in the beginning of the game (minor spoiler) when he lockpicks a bishop's office all by himself and expects everyone to believe in what he's found. Dr. Waston isn't much better because he, in my opinion, is a yes man who serves as Holmes' bottom b*itch; he is constantly manipulated by Holmes and the game does have him question some of Holmes' decisions, but in the end, he still blindly follow Holmes because of reasons. Also, you switch control between these two sometimes, but there is absolutely no point because they control EXACTLY the same.

2. The Story: I must admit, I was first intrigued by the beginning (A high ranking bishop was tortured and killed), but as it progressed, it got convoluted to the point of being stupid. Spoiler warning: The overall story is that Moriarty was hired by someone (We never know by who) to overthrow the Queen and replace her with the Prince through magic poison (No, I'm not kidding) and bombs. Plot points are thrown at you with no explanation (Or that Holmes won't tell you until the end) and when he finally tells you everything in an exposition dump,  it doesn't make much sense and he tell you in a very smug tone to imply that he is the only one who can stop them.

3. The Puzzles: The exploring parts were ok (Think of the Walking Dead movement scheme). The sixth sense button was a nice idea, but it worked when it wanted to (Sometimes, I clicked it and no buttons came up until I was right next to the object I was supposed to look at). The actual puzzles were hit or miss with mostly misses because most of the puzzles came with no explanations on the actual mechanics of them (Meaning that the puzzle would be figure out the mysterious substance in the test tube" and it didn't explain how to actually do that. reviewText:
Pretty decent investigative adventure (point and click) game.  I recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the original Sherlock Holmes stories by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.  It too me about 14 hours to complete.

Although the story is dark and not for children, it largely feels like something a modern Sir AC Doyle would write (which I thought was good).  At times, its tone can be off-putting, but once you reach the final act, it moves along quite well.  The end left me with an unresolved question though...

The visuals are particularly good with rich textures and high-quality models of people and late-19th century London.  The lip-sync algorithm is rather poor for parts of the game.  Any facial effects on the kids from the intro scene look bad.

Character control is clunky when turning in small quarters.  In open areas, it's just fine.

The game's puzzles range from a couple quite simple ones to some which are complex.  When stuck in an environment puzzle, make sure to check if you can combine items in your inventory as well as checking the local area for items you may have missed.

reviewText:
Being an avid fan of Sherlock Holmes games, I have to say this had the most compelling story so far. Although its predecessors were also very intriguing, their plots twists and endings were somewhat obvious, because most gamers were very familiar with stories of Arsene Lupin, Jack the Ripper and Lovecraft. This one kept me interested and guessing throughout the game and I was pleasantly surprised with the ending. Some small details may put you off in the beginning but rest assured that all will be very neatly explained towards the end a la Sherlock Holmes fashion. It is very nicely paced also and character driven instead of the usual murder mystery thriller style, which works very well with the theme and feels fresh.
Apart from the story, the gameplay is easy to get used to but you can still see the console port forced in there when you look at the user interfaces.  A point&click camera angle can be used to bypass this effect but the menus remain the same of course.

Looking at the mechanics involved (besides the puzzles), one thing that really fascinates me is that almost every Sherlock Holmes game tries to invent some new gameplay element. Don't get me wrong I don't mind designers experimenting with the gameplay but I expect the see the good ones becoming permanent mechanics in the series. For example, the Ripper murder scene investigation method is gone now, which is a pity. There seems to be a dialogue wheel present in the game which serves no purpose whatsoever. Deduction board is still fun and there is a very good puzzle element involved with it. But sadly the game does not use it very often, for reasons unknown to this reviewer. Inventory puzzles are not annoying contrary to the rest of the genre. But pixel hunting nightmares strike once or twice during the game (I encourage gamers to consult a walkthough at these points because they're not worth wasting time over, you should just get on with the story instead). The game would have been a better one without them sure but none of these gets in our way of enjoying the story and marveling at Sherlock’s wit and prowess.

Putting aside all these bumps, the game plays well and is long enough to satisfy the average user (15 hours).  Board puzzles are nicely done and interact with the world in a sensible way (as far as these sort of games go).  Watson and Sherlock’s dialogues are smart and funny as always and the delivery is very good, though the pace is a bit off; you get too long pauses between some lines that were obviously meant to be interrupting each other. You are still being provided with lots of documents and papers throughout the game (which is nice), some of which you need to read and understand in order to solve puzzles. Locations look very nice but they aren’t many but the Baker St. flat is there as always. Familiar faces pop up once in a while if you know who’s who. The murders are very gruesome and creative. The game is not very difficult also so in a way it feels like a smooth ride if you can overlook stuff mentioned above.

So all in all, Testament of S. Holmes is good follow up to his predecessors and if you’re a fan of the previous games, you should definitely get it. If you like point&click adventures, the story is enough reason to pick this one up. But if you’re new to the genre, don’t start here.

Pros: very good story, well designed puzzles, true to its source material, familiar voice acting, long gameplay,

Cons: UI looks very old, locations are sparse, some near misses with gameplay mechanics

Verdict: 4/5

reviewText: This was the first game I played in the series of The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, by Frogwares and Focus. I was skeptical at first, because I originally bought it in a $5 bin at a game store (and this was just after it had been released). I can only guess as to why this is, but after playing the game, it would be a very educated guess. Since then, I have voraciously consumed the series, and any games developed by Frogwares. I had falsely believed that a Russian developer could not do the character justice, and I apologize to them for this prejudgement. My review is not all blind praise, however. Some of the puzzles are very difficult, which is normally preferred in a puzzle game, but many of the puzzles do not even state the objective. I found myself spending nearly 45 minutes trying to figure out what was being asked of me as I placed blocks on a lockbox in a childrens classroom. Mostly, these puzzles give an overwhelming sense of satisfaction once you've mastered the objective. The story left nothing to be desired, true to form for the great detective, and although the visuals are less than Next-Generation, I found myself enraptured by the characters and deduction involved. I sincerely felt as Dr. John Watson feels: compelled to follow and trust Holmes, and severely angered when it seems he betrays my trust. Ever since I first played Maniac Mansion, I have been a fan of Point-and-Click adventures, but this series turned me into a full fledged fanatic. If you crave good storylines, enjoy Sherlock Holmes (who doesn't?), or just Love puzzle games, you can't go wrong with The Testament of Sherlock Holmes. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Meh.

Pros:
The story was, in it's entirety, quite good.... very similar to the Reichenbach Fall. I was dubious about how this game would be playable at all, because the charm of Sherlock Holmes is that his mind functions completely differently from a normal human being. Putting yourself in his place kinda defeats the purpose of Sherlock because his one awesome trait is gutted. They did a good job of allowing the player to experience the workings of his mind as an outsider.

Cons:
There were points in this game where I felt myself actually falling asleep. My playtime isn't anything close to 25 hours, there were a couple occasions where I found myself closing my eyes and just went to bed without closing the game. Also, even when you save your game, it takes you back to the start of the level, which means it makes more sense to just leave the game running in the background instead of quitting because you'll lose a good chunk of your progress. This game is similar to the Telltage Games where it's basically a point and click adventure. Everything is very linear, there's no real gameplay beyond a few really simple logic puzzles and clicking around on things. The voice acting is very, very, VERY wooden. The UI is pretty terrible. The maps are very static.... With rare exception, nothing movies, nobody interacts with the environment, and the vast majority of those exceptions are during cutscenes. I was shocked that such a small game took something like 9gb to install. I think we're advanced enough that we could have a dynamic room to actually pick around and gather clues instead of a very-static room. It felt almostl ike 7th guest, which I played 20 years ago. You'd think we would have moved on past that.

There's no replay value unless you want to speedrun it, and then you must be really bored.

Also, during the final credits, it plays a new song and does these really aweesome Guy Ritchie stylized credits. It makes you wonder Why the hell did they put so much creativity and effort into the credits when the game is bad enough that very few people actually bother getting to them? Why did I have to listen to the same 1 or 2 songs when they had this pretty awesome song just waiting for the rare times that someone gets to the credits?

2/5"

reviewText:
I grew up as a Sherlock Fan, so I try to get my hand on anything Holmesian.  All the other games in this series came out before 2008, so the old graphic prevented me from playing the game through.  That is why I was delighted when I saw the trailer for this game on TV.  Wow, an adventure game making a TV spot!  It must be good!  I guess the fact the BBC mini-series was so popular helped.

I bought this game on Steam when it was on sale through Humble Bundle in Oct 2013, and it took me about 3 month on and off to finish it.  I guess my mind has been too used to fast paced shooters and could never play for more than 30-60 minutes at a time.  Nevertheless, I enjoyed the time.  It took me about 17 hours to finish and that is with the help of looking up answer online.
There are a lot of puzzles, but I suppose that is what you want in a thinking game.  Sherlock has to unlock a lot of… well locks.  The puzzle basically all makes sense, but a LOT of them does not give instruction on how to solve it.  I guess that is real life, there is no instructional manual.
If you stare at a puzzle for about 5 minutes, then the game give you a chance to just skip the puzzle and get on with story.

This game does feature a nice story.  As I play through it I do enjoy the twist and turn.  You get to play Sherlock, Watson, and even their dog Toby.  You cannot die in the game, nor is there any timed puzzle.  Despite the trailer showing a lot of brandishing of guns, and a lot of graphic depiction of dead bodies, most of the game involves non-violent solution where you have to trap someone or create distraction to sneak past an obstacle.

There are some confusing story plot points.  One is the chase of the suspect Henry to Wharf 321, for me it did not make sense how it fit into the main plot.  Another one is when Sherlock brought cake to Judge Beckett’s house, it is the only times in the game where you see him carry something, but why would he carry cake?   I know about the plot twist in the end but it was never explained well.

It is fun to see Sherlock and all the gothic element of the Victorian era.  Watson came off as a well-rounded character; he did serve in the Afghan War and definitely uses his medical skill in the game.  Sherlock is cool as always.  The graphic is pretty good.  So play it if you are an adventure fan, and play it if you like a good mystery, just know there is no arcade action at all in here.

This is one of the best adventures games I've ever played.  The story was deep and immersive with unpredictable twists and turns.  Too many games lead down the same take it or leave it, predictable path but this game grips you and doesn't let go until the very last, moving cut scene.  This is the first Sherlock Holmes game I've played and I'm so pleased I chose this one as I can't see any others matching or surpassing this one.

One of the highlights for me was the way the games AI populated the Victorian world with an array of believable and authentic looking people, whether they be poverty stricken waifs and strays or high society.  I love just looking out the windows of their Baker Street room and watching the world pass by!

There's just one niggle that spoiled the gameplay at times and that was the AI controlling Watson.  When you're controlling Holmes, and Watson isn't off completing his own mission, Watson has this urge to get right up close to Holmes which often impedes Holmes' movement.  After a while you start to anticipate this behaviour and you go round him before he corners you.  It's an annoyance but overall didn't spoil the game and there are plenty of locations where they explore separately and hence this isn't an issue.

Pros:

*Character Driven Storyline
*Rich, Detailed Locations
*Excellent Voice Acting
*Cinematic Cut Scenes
*Perfect Soundtrack
*Thought Provoking Puzzles
*20+ Hours Gameplay

Cons:

*AI - Character Movement

If you enjoy adventure games you'd be a fool not to play this one!

reviewText:
The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is a good compromise between old-style adevnture games and new-era 3D adventure games with richer stories and cutscenes. It's also better than its sequel which emphasizes too much on the new-era style.

The variety of the puzzles is enjoyable and almost everyone is decently implemented. The good thing is that every puzzle is integrated in the scenario and not here just for the purpose or making your brain working (I do not like point and click games like Myst). The difficulty is also not too high and not too low, decently made overall even if the difficulty does not improve over time.

The gameplay is really good if you play on first person mode, OK at third person. I chose the last option because I like viewing my character but sometimes I switched to FP mode because of the limitations of the TP mode. In fact, it's harder to target a location sometimes while in TP mode. Still, it's not horrible to play, just a bit harder. I played it with both gamepad and mouse/keybord and I prefer the first option even if I'm an old PC player.

The graphics are OK technically speaking and retranscribe well the londonish atmosphere. English voices (which were impossible to pair with french subtitles - which was not a problem because I understand english - even with the developpers tips for steam version) are really well made, especially Holmes voice which retranscribes well the personality of the character.

The narrative part is nice even if some events seem far-fetched like what we can see in spectacular american movies. I enjoyed the whole plot and the narrative which is really above the pack for this type of games (without the sacrifice of the gameplay like in telltale games). The whole story is well critten and I admit I doubted about Holmes loyalty. Maybe the last chapter in the amusement park was a bit disappointing but still good.

Finally, this game is really solid. I recommend it strongly to people who enjoy a good mix between narrative and old-style puzzles. Sherlock Holmes games are really the best adventure games series nowadays  even if the last episode orientation is disturbing.

reviewText:
Overall, I liked The Testament of Sherlock Holmes. It has some technical flaws, which make it not the greatest game, but I'm glad I played it.

Pros:
+ The game has a really good, really strong Sherlock Holmes feel. This is not a game that they slapped a Sherlock skin on top of. It's got that special something that makes it Sherlock Holmes. This was the most important reason why I enjoyed the game overall, in spite of some flaws.
+ Good story. Nice twists an turns.
+ Good mixture of point and click, puzzle, and deduction elements. The deduction puzzles make it feel very Sherlocky.

Cons:
- A little too much pixel-hunting in the point and click. A couple of times I had to consult a walkthrough because I missed picking up some tiny item in a large level. A couple of the point and click puzzles are annoying.
- The story (while good overall) is framed with a really stupid meta-narration that kills the mood from time to time. Also I did not like the ending at all.
- Game starts to drag a little towards the end, where there is an extended and annoying last level. I was ready for it to be over.

reviewText:
Right off the bat I can say that The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is my favorite P&C from frogware with the master detective.

Pros:
- many a great puzzle and a skip option if you get really stuck
- a dense murder mystery with few but good twists thrown inbetween
- lovely sets, nice little details
- goodish graphics
- I love the voice acting
- deduction board for cases

Cons:
- animation is still stiff and borderline silly
- looong loading times

Verdict:

The Testament of Sherlock Holmes is an above average 3D point and click adventure.
You get to control Holmes, and on occasion Dr Watson, through a great story that covers a lot of ground.
From the lowliest slums to the high society, you will be dragged through many well designed set pieces on your hunt.
Fans of both Sherlock Holmes and P&C should give this a serious consideration (given that you survive the creepy intro)

reviewText:
Spoilers Ahead.

First of all, I just want to thank Frogwares for making this game. I for one am I Sherlock Holmes fan, and have played most of Frogware's titles. The thing about their previous games within my experience are, they tend to glitch out at the point where I'm not able to proceed and finish the game. The Silver Earrings. I got stuck in the master's office. The Awakened. Watson wasn't able to follow up in order for the cutscene. Jack the Ripper. It didn't allow me to interact with clues without pulling me into the inspection of A. Chapman. This is the 2nd title I've finish from Frogwares. The 1st being Sherlock Holmes vs. Nemesis (Arsen Lupin). What I'd like to point out about Frogwares is that within their storylines, they tend to blow things out of proportion and pulling straws out of the blue in order to progress. In this game, they've managed to do the same thing with very nice and touching plot twists.
The gameplay portion of it surely improved a lot from the previous games. The interface is beautiful, along with the enhanced graphics and such. From its predecessors, it was from an omniscience point of view. First-person was then added in the series, finally third-person. It gave their gamers a versatile choice. Allowing to use mouse only, keyboard only, and mouse and keyboard. It's an improved feature, but some of the time you'll have to switch between the views in order to interact with some of the clues. I did enjoy the 360 angle inspection feature, truely great idea. All in all, they certainly evolved this series from a point-and-click adventure to something similar to L.A. Noire, another great title. The only thing you really need a guide for are the puzzles, anything else is self-explained and you just need to explore and interact more.
Moving along with the storyline. Now with this game's story, it's not neccesary for playing some of the older games; however, it'll be somewhat helpful to understand just a bit. The story just slowly let's the gamers view that Sherlock does some questionable things. Slowly tarnishing his name and reputation, also making some of the gamers not liking him. The authors surely did a great job doing so, in order for some plot twists. Then there's the whole taking things out of proportion. First scene shows of three toddlers, and how they're connected to Sherlock and John. Moving on with the story it appears to be that they're grand children of Sherlock and John. How Sherlock, one of the greatest minds can also become the greatest criminal, ruined his reputation by handling the rich with a fake heirloom, rigging a bomb to murder a judge, and murdering an inspector. Here comes the first great plot twist as it was Moriarty whom set to frame Sherlock. Graspped from the straws, because in the previous games (The Awakned) Moriarty has lost his mind and was in an asylum. Though it did eliminated the possibility of him being behind all of it. Then it was grasping straws by pulling in the Prince by teaming him with Moriarity. Second great plot tiwst was that Moriarty has been hiding a child of his own all this time. After his last breathe, he told only Sherlock is worthy of teaching her. Sherlock moved by it raised the child from child to adult. From a beautiful young woman, to a married woman. The girl then birthed a child, a young girl. The girl from the first scene. This was a great scene, as it showed Sherlock didn't turn away from one of his most ignored subject. Love.

PROS: This is a great story for any Sherlock Holmes fan. While they changed the voice actor for Sherlock from the previous games, he still fits the character, and it still nods to the older adventures in the series. It has a very enticing and dark story. The game had a really good ending, and much more eventful than some of Frogware's previous installments. The puzzles are very challenging, fun, and like to use tricks or red herrings. The visuals are a great improvement over the rest of the games. Doctor Watson finally gets some good action, and is able to show that he's not just someone to bounce ideas off of.

CONS: I really enjoyed the deduction board in Sherlock Holmes versus Jack the Ripper, and it felt much more dumbed down and plain in this game.

10/10 would investigate a third time
